Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First I notice that each event has a timestamp activity resource department patient age patient gender and additional info Since these are separate patient journeys I can probably group them by patient age and gender but I should be careful because multiple patients could have the same age and gender But maybe the sequence of activities and departments can help distinguish them Okay so we have three distinct patient registrations at the beginning events 1 2 3 each with different ages and genders Event 1 45yearold male ER department private insurance Event 2 62yearold female ER department public insurance Event 3 28yearold male Surgery department private insurance

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now lets see how the subsequent events align with these initial registrations Starting with the 45yearold male Event 1 Event 1 Register patient ER Event 4 Initial triage ER same age and gender Event 7 Xray imaging Radiology same age and gender Event 12 Doctor consultation ER same age and gender diagnosishairlinefracture Event 15 Patient discharged ER same age and gender That seems to form a complete journey for the 45yearold male registration triage Xray doctor consultation discharge Next the 62yearold female Event 2 Event 2 Register patient ER Event 5 Initial triage ER same age and gender Event 8 Lab test requested ER same age and gender Event 10 Lab test completed Laboratory same age and gender Event 11 Doctor consultation ER same age and gender diagnosisminorinfection Event 14 Prescription created ER same age and gender Event 17 Patient discharged ER same age and gender This also forms a complete journey registration triage lab test requested lab test completed doctor consultation prescription discharge Finally the 28yearold male Event 3 Event 3 Register patient Surgery Event 6 Doctor consultation Surgery same age and gender reasonscheduledknee_surgery Event 9 Surgery preparation Surgery same age and gender Event 13 Surgery performed Surgery same age and gender Event 16 Recovery room Surgery same age and gender Event 18 Patient discharged Surgery same age and gender This journey makes sense as well registration doctor consultation surgery preparation surgery performed recovery room discharge

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now lets check if there are any events that dont fit into these three groups or if any events could belong to multiple groups All events seem to fit neatly into one of the three groups based on age gender and department To confirm lets list the events by case Case 1 45yearold male Event 1 Register patient ER Event 4 Initial triage ER Event 7 Xray imaging Radiology Event 12 Doctor consultation ER Event 15 Patient discharged ER Case 2 62yearold female Event 2 Register patient ER Event 5 Initial triage ER Event 8 Lab test requested ER Event 10 Lab test completed Laboratory Event 11 Doctor consultation ER Event 14 Prescription created ER Event 17 Patient discharged ER Case 3 28yearold male Event 3 Register patient Surgery Event 6 Doctor consultation Surgery Event 9 Surgery preparation Surgery Event 13 Surgery performed Surgery Event 16 Recovery room Surgery Event 18 Patient discharged Surgery

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Everything seems to fit nicely The departments and activities align with what youd expect for each patients journey For example the 28yearold male is in the Surgery department throughout his journey which makes sense given the surgeryrelated activities The other two cases are in the ER department which aligns with their activities like triage lab tests and consultations One thing to note is that the 45yearold males journey includes an Xray which is consistent with the diagnosis of a hairline fracture Event 12 The 62yearold females journey includes lab tests and a prescription for antibiotics consistent with a minor infection diagnosis Event 11 The 28yearold males journey is all about surgery from preparation to recovery There are no overlapping events or attributes that would suggest any mixing between the cases Each case has a unique combination of age gender and department trajectory
